sentences: The bus is stopping at the corner.
He stops when the light turns red.
Yesterday, she stopped at the store.

prompts.stem: Build a matrix for this base. Select words that keep the base spelling stable, then prove one with a word sum and a join note. After that, try spelling the whole word using your join reasoning (feedback only).

questions.text: In the sentence context, what does <stopping> mean?
What is the base that carries the core meaning across the matrix words?
Use the matrix to generate related words that keep the base spelling stable. Select at least four.
Choose one selected word and write a word sum that resembles it. Include a join note.
Optional: Spell the whole word using your word sum + join note (feedback only).

supports.content: The base in this word family is <stop> because it carries the core meaning across related words.
Join note: The spelling changes by ________ because ********.
Spelling rebuild (optional): Start with <stop>. Apply the join step. Add the suffix to spell <********>.

response.spelling_rebuild_prompt: Optional: Type the final spelled word you built from your word sum and join note.

rubric.criterion: Selects multiple matrix-buildable words that preserve the base spelling
Produces a word sum proof that resembles the chosen word
Includes a join note supported by letter evidence
Attempts to spell the whole word from the word sum + join note (feedback only)

metadata.notes_for_teacher: This task highlights the doubling convention for CVC bases before vowel suffixes (<-ing>, <-ed>). Students should notice that the base spelling <stop> stays stable, and the final consonant doubles at the join. Spelling rebuild is optional and used for feedback, not gating.
